Because of this 10 years of telehealth experience crammed into 3 months‚Äîpatients, doctors, nurses, therapists, and caregivers can write some new rules of the road, and we should do so while the experiences still are fresh on our minds.
Even with an event as significant as COVID-19, memories fade and attention moves quickly to the next crisis, so it is important for Congress to act on legislation this year.
One of those recommendations was to make sure that patients do not lose the benefits that they have gained from using telehealth during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Last week, I released a white paper on steps that Congress should take before the end of the year in order to get ready for the next pandemic.

2) permanently extend the policy change that nearly doubled the number of telehealth services that could be reimbursed by Medicare. There were 29 other temporary federal policy changes that could also be considered for being made permanent.

The federal government should 1) permanently extend policy changes that allowed physicians to be reimbursed for a telehealth appointment wherever the patient is located, including the patient‚Äôs home, and‚Ä¶
...and also to find out if there are any additional federal policies that would help patients and health care providers take advantage of delivering medical services using telehealth.
One purpose of this hearing is to find out which of these temporary changes in federal policy should be maintained, modified, or reversed...

Part of this explosion in remote meetings between patients and physicians has been made possible by temporary changes in federal and state policies. The private sector, too, has made important changes.
Our job should be to ensure that change is done with the goals of better outcomes and better patient experiences at a lower cost.

In 2016, there were almost 884 million visits nationwide between patients and physicians, according to the @CDCgov. If 15-20% of those were to become remote permanently due to telehealth expansion during COVID-19‚Äîthat would produce a massive change in our health care system.

As dark as this pandemic event has been, it creates an opportunity to learn from and act upon these three months of intensive telehealth experiences, specifically what permanent changes need to be made in federal and state policies.

I know that type of grace can only come from God. Of all the things that I've seen in public life, the words from the family members continue to amaze me to this day. You must truly have the love of the Lord in your heart to be able to muster that kind of forgiveness.

Then just days after this horrible tragedy, the people at Mother Emanuel showed a level of love and forgiveness that was truly unimaginable. It was an act that is rarely seen. I personally cannot imagine turning to the person who killed my family members saying I forgive you.

It remains hard to understand how anyone could have so much hate in their heart. To be welcomed into a church, worship with the parishioners, and then turn around and shoot them in cold blood remains one of the most horrific acts ever recorded.
Five years have passed and it still feels like a bad dream, but we know it actually happened. The senseless murder of nine parishioners at Mother Emanuel hit South Carolina like a ton of bricks.

Those are some of the initiatives I'm pursuing as communities across Central Virginia strive for equal opportunity & equal justice for all. I'm thankful for the many Black voices in Virginia and in the House whose leadership has laid the foundation on which we all build. (10/10)

4. 21st Century STEM for Girls and Underrepresented Minorities Act. I cosponsored this bill to empower local school districts to engage more girls and minority students in STEM fields, an area where Black and Latino Americans continue to be underrepresented. (9/10)

3. Equitable Data Collection and Disclosure on COVID-19 Act. I cosponsored this bill because it's clear that minority communities are suffering disproportionately high fatality rates during this pandemic. We need consistent demographic data related to COVID-19. (8/10)

2. Justice for Victims of Lynching Act and the Emmett Till Antilynching Act. I'm a cosponsor of these bills, which would establish new criminal penalties for lynching. Our nation has a long history with this brutal crime, and we must do more to confront it & eradicate it. (7/10)

1. The "Momnibus" package, which I helped introduce in March, works to address our appalling, racially-divided maternal mortality rates. In Virginia, across all levels of income & education, Black mothers are 3 times more likely to die during childbirth that white mothers. (6/10)

Our calls of #BlackLivesMatter must be backed up by progress not just on criminal justice, but also on education, maternal mortality, and more. Here are some of the other equity-focused bills that I will continue fighting to move forward in the weeks and months to come: (5/10)

The Justice in Policing Act would ban chokeholds and no-knock warrants, create a nationwide police misconduct registry, limit the transfer of military-grade equipment to local police departments, and require state & local agencies to report use-of-force data. (4/10)

I thank @TheBlackCaucus, including my colleague @RepKarenBass, for her work on this legislation. I support this bill, and I hope my colleagues - Democrats & Republicans - will recognize the clear imperative to make our communities safer for all, especially Black Americans. (3/10)

I‚Äôve listened to a range of diverse views on this topic, from across #VA07, including hearing from local law enforcement about how they feel we can rebuild a strong sense of community-driven policing. There is clear room for progress on these issues. (2/10)

I'm cosponsoring the Justice in Policing Act of 2020. We cannot repeat the voter suppression that happened in Wisconsin and Georgia. 

We need vote by mail. And we need to work to expand the vote so every single voice is heard ‚Äì¬†that is the only way we will have a government that reflects the values of those it represents.

We need universal vote by mail. We need ranked-choice voting. We need automatic voter registration. We need extended early voting for primary races. We need online portals so voters can access information and apply for ballots from their phones.

But let‚Äôs be clear ‚Äì In Massachusetts, we should be leading on this issue. It's our duty to expand access to voting any way that we can. We need to expand voter access for every election in this state.

I applaud the MA Legislature for the vote by mail measures they have passed to help keep voters safe during this pandemic and am thankful to the Election Laws Committee who allowed me to testify on this important legislation.
No one should be forced to weigh their constitutional right to vote against their health and safety. Period.
